title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, resources for transportation research and development have remained stagnant. There is a need for more funding and a focus on long-term strategic research through competitive, peer-reviewed awards. The diversity of transportation research programs presents challenges in addressing the needs of different customers. The importance of research and development for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals is emphasized. To address long-term strategic research needs, competitive, peer-reviewed funding is recommended. Challenges arise from the diversity of transportation research programs, making effective priority setting difficult. Increasing federal investment in long-range transportation planning, supporting competitive research, and better coordinating research and development are key to ensuring the United States transportation system meets its goals. The United States aims to increase federal investment in long-range transportation planning, support competitive research into systemic transportation issues, better coordinate research programs, foster data interchange, and establish nationwide priorities in transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The Center's duties include supporting competitive research, coordinating research programs, fostering data interchange, and establishing nationwide priorities in transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions will develop a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation. It will support projects with public benefits, offer grants to research institutions, and facilitate data interchange among interested parties in the United States. The National Center for Transportation Solutions supports long-term transportation objectives through grants to research institutions, facilitates data interchange among interested parties, evaluates government research programs, and submits annual reports to Congress on activities. The Director of National Transportation Research evaluates US Government transportation research programs and submits annual reports to Congress on activities, including recommendations for multimodal transportation research. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President. Members must represent various professions and sectors. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by different authorities, with qualifications including representing various professions, regions, and possessing relevant skills. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve staggered 6-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members serve staggered 6-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. Terms are staggered with initial members serving for different lengths of time. Members' terms do not expire during election years. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members serve staggered 6-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. Terms are staggered with initial members serving for different lengths of time. Vacancies in the Board are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and meet at the call of the Chair. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, and the Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members. The Board members serve staggered 6-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board shall meet at the call of the Chair, with a majority constituting a quorum. A Chairman and Vice Chairman are selected from among its members for 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms as Chairman. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director's term is six years, with a salary capped at the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Center's organization is outlined in Section 7. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee composed of at least five members serving two-year terms, with an annual Chairman election. Each division committee consists of at least five members, who may or may not be Board members, serving two-year terms. The committee elects a Chairman annually and sets its own procedural rules within Board restrictions. SEC. 8. POWERS OF CENTER. The division committee consists of at least five members serving two-year terms and elects a Chairman annually. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, enter into contracts, and use postal services to carry out the purposes of the Act. Additionally, the Board can enter into agreements with entities like the National Academy of Sciences for studies to develop policies and strategies. The Board and division committees have the authority to conduct hearings, gather information, enter contracts, and use postal services. They can also enter into agreements with entities like the National Academy of Sciences for studies. Additionally, they can accept gifts, publish research results, and dispose of donations. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center may appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The staff is responsible for submitting strategic and annual plans, developing budgets, administering programs, providing support to the Board, and reporting on program progress. They also coordinate with personnel from other organizations. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff responsibilities include submitting plans, developing budgets, providing support to the Board, and coordinating with personnel from other organizations. The Director can set compensation for Center personnel without regard to certain pay regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff responsibilities include submitting plans, developing budgets, providing support to the Board, and coordinating with personnel from other organizations. The Director can set compensation for Center personnel without exceeding the rate payable for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement, and volunteer services can be accepted without regard to certain regulations. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director will award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States by September 30, 2005. These centers will conduct research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with public benefits and where private investment is necessary. The northeast regional center will be located in one of the top 5 states with high traffic congestion on National Highway System roads. The northeast regional center will be located in one of the 5 States with the highest levels of traffic congestion in the United States, based on specific criteria related to National Highway System roads. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
